conclusion: Trying to solve the Millikan oil-drop experiment problem step by step.
Two metal plates separated by distance d, oil droplets sprayed through a hole, acquiring electric charges.
Two oil droplets, A and B, each with mass m_0, falling with uniform velocity through distance h_1 in time t.
Voltage U applied across plates, upper plate positive, droplet A continues to fall, droplet B moves upwards with uniform velocity through distance h_2 in time t.
Droplets merge to form a new droplet, continuing to move between plates until reaching uniform velocity.
Air resistance on spherical oil droplet is f = k m^{1/3} v, where k is proportionality constant, m is mass, v is velocity.
Need to find proportionality constant k.
Before voltage is applied, both droplets falling with uniform velocity, net force is zero, gravity and air resistance balanced.
After voltage is applied, droplet A continues to fall, electric force balances change in air resistance.
Droplet B moves upwards, indicating electric force dominates upward direction.
Consider how masses and charges combine when droplets merge.
Before voltage applied: Gravity m_0 g downward, Air resistance f = k m_0^{1/3} v upward.
Electric force negligible or balanced before voltage applied.
For uniform motion: m_0 g - k m_0^{1/3} v = 0, thus v = m_0^{2/3} g / k.
Both droplets have same mass m_0 and velocity v, but different distances h_1 and h_2.
h_1 and h_2 are distances traveled in time t, not necessarily related to masses or charges.
Before voltage applied, both droplets falling with uniform velocity v, so h_1 = v t.
After voltage applied, droplet A continues to fall at velocity v, new position h_1 + v t.
Droplet B moves upwards with uniform velocity, position changes to h_2 = v t.
Electric field points downward when voltage applied, charged droplets experience force in field direction.
Droplet B experiences upward force greater than downward forces.
